questions.text: 1. A 40-year-old female, on administration of a neuromuscular blocker, developed erythema, flushing of face, neck, trunk, and hypotension. Which of the following drugs is responsible?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of histamine release. Atracurium is the most potent histamine releaser among the given options and was likely administered.

Based on the chemical structure, non-depolarising muscle relaxants (NDMR) can be classified into two groups: 

* Steroidal compounds: Pancuronium, Vecuronium, Rocuronium

* Benzylisoquinoline compounds: d-Tubocurarine, Atracurium, Cis-atracurium, and Mivacurium

Erythema, flushing, and hypotension are manifestations of histamine release. Histamine release is most likely associated with benzylisoquinoline compounds, except cis-atracurium, as compared to steroidal compounds. Cis-atracurium is a stereoisomer of atracurium and has negligible histamine-releasing potential despite being a benzylisoquinoline compound.

Management includes stopping or slowing the infusion of the NDMR and giving antihistamines. Hypotension can be prevented by giving antihistamines and non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs).

Pearl PM0247: Muscle relaxant with histamine release.

Muscle relaxants causing histamine release leading to hypotension, tachycardia, flushing:

Most likely: d-tubocurarine

Likely: 

* Atracurium

* Mivacurium

* Succinyl choline

Least likely:

* Vecuronium

* Cisatracurium

* Rocuronium

* Pancuronium

questions.text: 2. Following a building collapse, a male patient was brought with a copious amount of debris in the mouth. The following procedure was done. Which of the following statements regarding the given procedure is true?

choices.text: It is used for effective ventilation upto 6 hours
It is used to measure central venous pressure
Work of breathing is more than bag and mask ventilation
It should be followed by tracheostomy

questions.solution:
The true statement regarding the given procedure is that it should be followed by tracheostomy.

In this case, the presence of copious oral debris makes intubation and ventilation difficult, so a surgical airway is required. The image shows cricothyrotomy, a temporary emergency airway that must be followed by tracheostomy because of risks such as perichondritis, subglottic edema, and laryngeal stenosis.

If intubation fails, options include a laryngeal mask airway, laryngeal tube airway, or surgical airway. Surgical airway is indicated in airway obstruction from glottic edema, laryngeal fracture, or severe oropharyngeal bleeding. 

Cricothyrotomy can be of two types:

* Needle cricothyrotomy: A needle is introduced through the cricothyroid membrane to provide short-term ventilation. This may be combined with percutaneous transtracheal oxygenation at 15 L/min using a cannula and Y-connector. Intermittent insufflation (1 sec on, 4 sec off) provides oxygenation but inadequate CO2 clearance, so it is limited to 30-45 minutes.

* Surgical cricothyrotomy: A transverse incision is made over the cricothyroid membrane, and a tube is inserted. It is preferred in emergencies over tracheostomy as it is faster, easier, and associated with less bleeding.

Other options:

Option A: Surgical cricothyrotomy can be used for effective ventilation up to 24 to 48 hours. Needle cricothyrotomy can be used only for 30 to 45 minutes.

Option B: Cricothyrotomy is used for emergency airway management and not for the measurement of central venous pressure.

Option C: In cricothyrotomy, the upper airway is bypassed, resulting in less resistance to airflow. Therefore, the work of breathing in cricothyrotomy is less, not more, than with bag-mask ventilation.

questions.text: 3. A 50-year-old male with COVID developed ARDS and is on mechanical ventilation, with a PaO₂/FiO₂ ratio of 100. What is the most appropriate ventilator strategy for this patient?

choices.text: High PEEP and low tidal volume
Low PEEP and low tidal volume
High PEEP and high tidal volume
Low PEEP and high tidal volume

questions.solution:
The ventilator setting recommended for ARDS is high PEEP and low tidal volume.

Acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) is a clinical syndrome of severe dyspnea of rapid onset, occurring within 7 days of clinical insult, hypoxemia, bilateral pulmonary infiltrates, and may not demonstrate cardiomegaly, pleural effusions, leading to type 1 respiratory failure. Lung injury may be direct, as occurs in toxic inhalation, or indirect, as occurs in sepsis 

PaO2/FiO2 ratio is the ratio of arterial oxygen partial pressure (PaO2) to the fraction of inspired oxygen (FiO2). It is a key indicator of oxygenation.

ARDS severity is assessed using the PaO2/FiO2 ratio at a minimum PEEP of 5 cm H2O as per the Berlin Criteria:

Severity PaO2/FiO2 (mmHg)
Mild 200 - 300
Moderate 100 - 200
Severe ≤100


Recommended therapies in ARDS with clinical or supportive evidence:

* Low tidal volume: To avoid barotrauma due to overdistention of the alveoli.

* High PEEP (positive end-expiratory pressure): This prevents the collapse of alveoli at the end of expiration and improves oxygenation.

* Prone position

* Extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (ECMO)

questions.text: 4. General anesthetic sevoflurane and succinylcholine were administered to a patient undergoing abdominal surgery. Post operatively, patient developed persistent muscle contractions, hyperthermia and tachycardia. Which of the following drugs is life-saving in this situation?
questions.solution:
The life-saving drug for the given condition is Dantrolene.

The clinical picture of hyperthermia, tachycardia, and muscle rigidity following administration of sevoflurane and succinylcholine is characteristic of malignant hyperthermia, a genetic disorder caused by mutations in the RyR1 receptor of skeletal muscle. When exposed to triggering agents, the defective receptor leads to uncontrolled calcium release from the sarcoplasmic reticulum, resulting in persistent muscle contraction, increased heat production, acidosis, hyperkalemia, and elevated end-tidal CO2.

Patients with positive family history and patients with congenital myopathies are at increased risk for the development of this condition.

Drugs triggering malignant hyperthermia:

* Succinylcholine

* Halothane

* Isoflurane

* Sevoflurane

Dantrolene is a direct-acting skeletal muscle relaxant that acts on the RyR1 (ryanodine receptor) calcium channels in the sarcoplasmic reticulum of skeletal muscles and inhibits calcium-induced calcium release. This results in the uncoupling of membrane depolarization and muscle contraction, thus inhibiting muscle contraction.

Once the diagnosis is made, the causative inhalational agent should be stopped immediately. Supportive management includes rapid cooling, inhalation of 100% oxygen, control of acidosis, and treatment of hyperkalemia.

Pearl PM0183: Malignant hyperthermia key features

Pathophysiology:

* Prolonged opening of functionally altered ryanodine receptors, leading to uncontrolled release of calcium from the sarcoplasmic reticulum resulting in sustained muscle contraction.

Drugs known to trigger malignant hyperthermia:

* Inhaled anesthetics: Halothane, Isoflurane, Sevoflurane, Desflurane, Ether, Methoxyflurane

* Depolarising muscle relaxant: Succinylcholine

Clinical signs:

* Increased metabolism: Increased EtCO2, decreased SpO2, metabolic acidosis

* Increased sympathetic activity: Tachycardia, hypertension, arrythmia

* Muscle damage: Masseter spasm, generalised rigidity, hyperkalemia, rhabdomyolysis, myoglobinuria

* Hyperthermia: Fever, sweating

 Treatment: 

* Discontinuation of all anesthetic agents

* Hyperventilation with 100% O2

* Dantrolene: 2.5 mg/kg intravenously every 5 min until the episode is terminated (upper limit - 10 mg/kg).

* Correction of acid-base, electrolyte abnormality 

* Cooling the patient
